Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2009 11:30AM lcmag wrote: Hi Polly - I'm doing Taxol weekly, i just had my 4th on Friday the 26th, and #5 is on Friday October 2.  I'm a little weird, because I'm counting DOWN in my head.  I call this week #7, and next week is my halfway point at #6 taken, and 6 more to receive. My panic attacks came at the oddest of times - I obviously had called a number of my friends and family to let them know of the diagnosis, but when it came time to SEE these very same people, I started having panic attacks.  The first one came when I was on my way to my mother's house - I mean, it's my MOM for the love of pete!  Then I would get them on the way HOME from work when I had an appointment the following day. Did you ever get any medicine for panic attacks?  Does the ambein help you sleep?  I'm really considering asking for something, even if it's just for Sunday nights when the hot flashes are worst.  But I'll try taking the Ativan first, see if that helps.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2009 07:50AM lcmag wrote: Hello my friends! Just back from the doctor in prep for starting Taxol (12 treatments) on August 28th.  Thanks to you all here, I was able to talk to my doctor about the Benedryl, which I generally don't react well to, so THANK YOU!  I'm going to take an over the counter Benedryl the night prior and then will have half the amount of IV Benedryl. I also got a perscription for Nexium to start taking NOW because I already have a little bit of hearburn that will probably get worse. For Neuropathy:  Take 100mg of B6 and 60mg of Zinc EVERY DAY, begin this regimen prior to yoru first Taxol and you shouldn't struggle with it. The doctor also indicated that people who do 12 weekly treatments tend to fare better on the SEs because the dosage is smaller.  Of course, over time the SEs can get worse for those who do 12 treatments because of the cumulative effect. I was supposed to start this week, but i needed a break, i need to feel normal for a little bit.  In regard to the mojo issues, my fiancee and I have not cut this out entirely, but I do have some suggestions if you will bare with my directness:  1) make sure your partner isn't overly manscaped.  any stubble, heck even short hairs can cause a lot of pain.  2)  use a lubricant.  Astroglide is wonderful.  3) GO SLOWLY. it will hurt less, it will give the lubricant a chance to work its way into where it needs to be and as mentioned above, it DOES increase the sensuality of the act. Have a peaceful day, ladies.  Be well, take care, and hang in there!  Hugs to you all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 06:19AM lcmag wrote: TomnDi - CONGRATS!  What a releif it must be to both of you, to know that the cancer is GONE!  Rads will just make sure it doesn't come back. I'm shocked at the 4 month wait for BRAC test results, mine were back in 2 weeks, which was nice, because I was able to tailor my treatments based on those results. I can now count down my weekly taxol treatments on one hand!!!  5 more left then chemo will be behind me.  My good pal in the infusion room will be finishing up her Taxol on Friday, and they have this wonderful tradition of ringing a bell when you walk out from your last treatment. I cannot wait to see her ring that bell and walk out those doors, hopefully forever! I have not been taking the Zoloft prescribed by my oncologist for hot flashes.  Instead I'm taking 1000mg of Vit E daily and on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights using the Ativan to help me sleep.  It's doing the trick and I don't have to wait 2 weeks for the Zoloft to kick in and maybe work, maybe not. My fingernails are horrid, and my toenails are swiftly following suit.  I've chopped them down as far as I can, but they look just awful!  Eyebrows are coming in, but are so fine that you can hardly see them!  My hair is filling in nicely, I may be able to go without a scarf by the end of November! Do any of you have trouble keeping/getting warm after a particularly bad night of hot flashes/night sweats?  It happens to me one night per week, but I get so cold that I simply cannot warm up.  Layers of clothing and blankets, heating pad, hot shower....none of it helps.  It will releive itself in about 5 hours, but those 5 hours are tough.  They usually come around 3am, too.  Very strange! I hope everyone does well this week with treatments, s/es, whatever you have on your plate. Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 07:17AM lcmag wrote: Had Taxol #2 on Friday.  Thursday night I took the same meds (1 Benedryl, 1 Zantac Max, 3 decadron), but learned that this week, I will only take ONE decadron. The infusion was about 90 minutes, I felt slightly sleepy after the IV benedryl, but nothing terrible.  After treatment I went shopping at Kohl's. Friday night was fine - no SEs so to speak of, but I found it very hard to get to sleep, and to stay asleep.  The doctor said next week won't be as bad because I won't have as many of the steriods in my system. Saturday had a great day - the weather was perfect, I felt very, very good.  We went to look at a couple of houses, ate some great BBQ and really enjoyed the day. Sunday had a great morning and felt fine!  The fatigue didn't really start until the late afternoon, and I only needed one nap.  Sunday night wasn't so great, I'm really struggling with hot flashes at night (4 or 5 times), and while they only last a couple minutes, it's a disruption to your sleep that you really don't need. I haven't been experiencing any bone pain at all, which I know is a blessing. I saw my surgeon last week to check on swelling under my arm on the side of my axillary dissection - turns out that my new tote bag is too heavy and the straps are rubbing a 'void area' where a cluster of lyph nodes used to be (I had 26 removed).  The rubbing is causing fluid to fill the area, and the fluid is causing the swelling.  I did not realize how very careful I need to be when using this arm or carrying and lifting things with this arm.  It has only been 3 months since surgery, so I should give it more time and care. After this weeks' treatment, I will be halfway through with chemo.  It's a very exciting. Be well ladies.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 11:36AM lcmag wrote: Hello Ladies! I had #9 of 12 Taxol treatments last week, and tomorrow is #10 - 3 more treatments and 2 weeks until chemo is over for me.  I'd like to get very excited, but since I had that set back 2 weeks ago, and had to miss treatment, I know that things can change in a day.  So maybe I'll start getting excited after I get treatment tomorrow. My Onc still won't let me schedule the measuring appointment with the Radiologist, and I think he might have me wait 2 weeks after chemo ends - I had really hoped to go straight through to radiation after chemo, but now he's saying I'll need to let my body rest.  I guess I'm okay with that. My eyelashes are growing back and it's a little uncomfortable!  The stubble is very itchy and collects "eye crusties" all day long - a small price to pay, I know.  I'd really like to see more eyebrows, but they are staying away. My hair is growing like crazy, but not ALL over.  It's strange, the places where I had the 'fuzzies' during a/c are bald now.  The fuzzies fell out about 2 weeks into Taxol, but my other hair had started to grow back, so it has been strange.  If only the bald spots were in the back, I would be tempted to go out without my scarves. Do any of you have any swelling in your ankles/feet?  I've noticed that happening at the end of every day, some days it's tender, too. For those of you with bad neuropathy, have you tried the B6/Zinc combo?  Daily, take 100mg of B6 and 60mgs of Zinc.  That kept 99% of the neuropathy at bay for me until just recently.  I started adding glutamine powder as well at the recommendation of one of the oncology nurses, and the little tingles that started went away.  I strongly recommend both courses of action. Take care of yourselves today, ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 07:24AM lcmag wrote: ONE MORE TAXOL TREATMENT TO GO!!!! Good morning, ladies!  I'm on a bit of a high today, had #11 of 12 taxols on Friday.  My last chemotherapy treatment is in 4 days! Tomorrow I will go for my measuring appointment with the radiologist, it's scheduled to be 90 minutes.  I'm excited to get this started, because I had thought they were going to make me wait a couple weeks in between chemo & radiation. Edema in my ankles is getting very annoying and painful.  Well, perhaps pain isn't the proper word, but when parts of your ankle that shouldn't be, are rubbing against your shoes, it's disconcerting at best!  I'm trying to stay off my feet as much as possible, but I work full time and am packing to move, so I do what I can. Be good to yourselves today, ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 08:39AM lcmag wrote: Hello Ladies! I am so happy to hear so many of us are finishing up chemo!  I'm a week and a half out of chemo and my energy has really started coming back!!  My muscles are so weak that they get fatigued EASILY, but it's nice to be able to stay awake past 7pm. I have had my first three pre-radiation treatments, and have 3 tattoos the size of freckles.  I will probably have to get one more because I cannot have tape on my skin for longer than 10-15 minutes without having a severe reaction.  I still have the marks on my skin around my port-a-cath from the last chemo 11 days ago!  They really are the smallest things, and look just like freckles, so i'm not concerned with keeping them "forever." Oncologist suggested another study, but I'm not going to participate.  I'm still reeling from the Avastin study and too scared to put more chemicals into my body that may not NEED to be there.  I've had a horrible time with cysts the last 4 weeks of treatment (i currently have FIVE) and they are in a not-so-comfortable place.  I just want my body to heal and get back to living a more 'natural' life.  Chemicals aren't going to be a part of that for me. I start radiation on 12/7, the hospital is about 12 minutes away from work and less than 10 minutes from home, so it will be convenient. Be good to yourselves today!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2009 08:13AM lcmag wrote: Had a minor set back last week - developed an abcess that needed to be lanced, so my Onc said no chemo.  What a pain the ass.  Now I won't finish until the week prior to Thanksgiving, which means there is no hope of finished rads by the new year.  I guess cancer gets to ruin 2010, too! The abcess is healing nicely, I'm on antibiotics for another 2 days, so I don't anticipate having any issues receiving treatment this week. My eyelashes are growing back, and they look so strange!!  Little stubble on the eyelid, it's itchy, lol. Keep pushing on, ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2009 08:39AM - edited Nov 23, 2009 08:39AM by lcmag I am DONE with chemo!!!  Had #12 of 12 Taxol sessions on Friday.  At my cancer center when you are done with chemo, you righ a bell.  I ran the hell out of that bell and yelled "I DID IT!!"  I got a standing ovation, it was nice. I also had my first radiation measuring appointment on Wednesday of last week. I received my 3 'freckle sized' tattoos and will lie on my back during rads.  I have another measuring appointment this Wednesday, my simulation appointment on the 30th, then I start daily radiation on December 1st. I still won't be done by New Years, but at least I won't have too many left after new years. My toenail fell off yesterday, my hair is about an inch long and is all grey/white.  I still have lots of bald spots/thinning and no eyebrows to speak of. But at least it's OVER! YAY!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 11:29AM lcmag wrote: Rinna - That is exactly how I feel.  2009 was lost to cancer, and I'm not interested in donating more time to this awful disease. I did genetic testing as well because I was only 35 when diagnosed and my grandmother is a breast cancer survivor.  I did not test positive for either BRAC1 or BRAC2, but if I had, I was fully prepared to have a double mastectomy and have my ovaries removed.  For me, it's more about being DONE with cancer, and eliminating any possible chance that it could come back.  I would rather lose all my girlie parts and still be alive than run the risks of recurrance.  With my cancer type/stage, if you test positive for the genes, do chemo and rads (or chemo and mastectomy) you have a 12% chance of recurrance.  If you do not test positive for the genes, do the chemo/rads, chemo/mastectomy, the recurrance chances are 5%. However, I don't know about your chances of getting ovarian cancer AFTER a positive breast cancer diagnosis and treatment.  Does anyone else? My biggest fear right now is a recurrance, and I've not even completed treatment!  I considered a double mastectomy anyway, but both my oncologist and breast surgeon said it wasn't necessary at this point, that I was being too alarmist/aggressive.  But if I discover another lump, if I have to get yet another biopsy........ I think I'll go with the double mastectomy. Hang in there!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 12:11PM lcmag wrote: Had my first radiation treatment today! my appointments are at 11am.  It's a 12 minute drive over, 12 mins for chemo and 12 mins back to work - that's not even a lunch hour!  In preparation I used the calendula gel on my breast last night and this morning liberally applied corn starch to my breast and underarm because you can't use antipersperant/deoderant with the exception of Tom's of Maine deoderant.  I will need to go out and get some NON-underwire, 100% cotton bras -where the heck does one find them?  I don't know but will figure it out! So you park the car, walk into the radiation suite and have a seat.  At your scheduled time they call you back and you get changed into a gown (waist up) and sit in the waiting area.  One of the nurses comes to get you and you go into the radiation room, lay on the table.  The techs come and align your tattoos (i got an additional one today, that makes 4) then they leave and in about 3-4 minutes you're DONE! After the radiation I had some warmth in the area, and some tingle-zingy sensations.  The tingles and the warmth went away quickly, but the zingy feelings are still there and completely normal from what I am told. My tumor was only .9 centimeters, but I had 4 cancerous nodes out of the 26 that were removed, so stage IIIa for me.  My cancer was removed surgically prior to chemo - all my pre-chemo scans were clear so radiation is precautionary. I'm so happy for all of us starting to move along from this a little bit more each month!  2010 will be so much better for us all!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 06:14AM lcmag wrote: Had my first of 12 Taxol treatment on Friday (8/28). I wrote out this whole long post yesterday, but left it in preview and navigated away from the website, so it never posted!  Here I am trying again. Thursday night I was directed to take 1 over the counter Benedryl (25mg), 1 Xantac Max (150mg) and 12mg of Decadron (3 pills).  I slept fine and my appointment was at 10am. I had some blood drawn Friday morning, then saw the doctor who ASSURED me that these treatments wouldn't be as horrible as a/c.  I had been participating in a clinical trial with Avastin, but dropped out because a/c was so hard on me that I no longer wanted to put anything in my body that did not absolutely HAVE to be there.  After dropping out of the study I learned from the research nurse and another oncologist that people who receive the Avastin during the study always report worse SEs.  That is a little tidbit that I would have liked to have known PRIOR to entering into the study, but the water has long since flowed under that bridge. Taxol infusion was 90 minutes (compared to my usual 3+ hour a/c infusion) and I felt fine!  A little sleepy from the additional Benedryl that was administered via the iv, but other than that.....nothing!  Friday night I slept well, Saturday we had our usual weekend routine with NO injection interruptions.  On a/c I had to return to the hospital every day for 8 days to receive a neupergin shot. Sunday afternoon I started getting a little sleepy and feeling some fatigue. I didn't fight it, so I napped off and on through the afternoon and into the evening.  Monday I came to work - first time since starting chemo that I was actually able to work after chemo!  I didn't stay the whole day, because I was getting very tired, but I did stay until a bit after 1pm and then went home and napped. I did not feel nauseaus at all from the Taxol!  I did throw up yesterday, but that was because I took too many vitamins and not enough food for breakfast - my fault! I've been taking 100mgs of B6 and 60mgs of Zinc daily along with my multi-vitamin.  I also take a perscription nexium daily to combat the heartburn that the steriods cause.  Ask your doctors about doing the same.  Don't wait for issues to become a problem (like the heartburn and the neuropathy) before you address them! I am so happy that the SEs haven't been bad - and I did not have to have a Neulasta shot this first go-around, and I hope that continues.  My hair isn't growing back yet - but the peach fuzz I never lost has started to get a bit longer.  Maybe that is a sign that the rest of it may start poking through any day.  I can't tell you how often I stare into the mirror almost willing the hair follicles to grow, dammit!  I'm so sick of being bald.  I just want enough coverage to feel confident going out of the house without my scarves.  I have a wig that I haven't worn even once!  It's been so hot here this summer, and the wig is terribly itchy and hot. My fingernails have started doing really peculiar things, but someone who traveled this road before us suggested cutting the painful nails down as short as you can - and that has helped.  I'm not sure what can be done about the bumps in the nail bed or the digs and ridges..... i don't much care about it being unsightly, as long as it doesn't hurt!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2009 01:26PM lcmag wrote: Hello all - I'm joining the group late!  I started Chemo on 6/25.  4 A/C treatments and 12 on Taxol.  I had my last A/C on 8/6 and was sick for a full week, par usual. My treatments were on Thursday afternoons. I had emend and decatron along with Zofran (Compazine gave me a bad reaction).  I had nausea from Saturday - Thursday, vomiting from Sunday night to Wednesday night.  The doctor isn't sure why I had such a hard time. I'm taking a week off this week and starting Taxol on 8/28.  I was supposed to start this week, but have been so weak and tired that I just couldn't bring myself to do it.  I know all the same things will be there in a weeks time, but I need the mental separation. I hope to make this journey with you and I hope that we'll see the end of all this soon. Be strong, ladies!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 06:55AM lcmag wrote: Hello Ladies! I had my third Taxol treatment on Friday, and things are going well!  Infusion was 90 minutes, which seems to be the norm.  My white blood cell counts were a little low, but I did not have to have a neulasta or neupagin shot.  My fingernails are starting to fall off!  It's oddly fascinating, really.  At first, the nail was so painful at the bed, then the pain went away, but i could feel a 'lifting' sensation at the top of the nail/finger.  This is happening to both thumbs and the middle finger on my right hand. My eyelashes are falling out, but I don't particularly care, as they have always been thin but the eyebrow loss is a little harder to deal with.  I'm getting severe thinning, and some holes.  I've never filled in with shadow or an eyebrow pencil, but I think I'll have to start. In terms of S/Es, the worst is still the fatigue on Sunday afternoon evening and I can only work a half day on Monday.  I've been religious about taking the 100 mgs of B6 and 60mgs of Zinc, and so far there has been no sign of neuropathy! The hot flashes are still my worst complaint - now it's a full on body sweat along with the hot flash, which comes about every 2 hours or so.  Getting a good nights' rest is challenging! My hair is not growing back - actually, all my fuzzies have been falling OUT over the weekend.  I bought 3 new scarves to add to my collection.  I'm still not thrilled with my wig, and it's just so hot!  I can't imagine how uncomfortable I'd be in that wig during these glorious hot flashes. When the S/Es are manageable, I feel more like a normal person, and then I look in the mirror : ( but i'm 3 treatments in, 9 more to go, and I can do this.  YOU can do this - we can do this together. Be well today, ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 09:30AM lcmag wrote: Hi Polly - That is interesting about waiting a couple weeks after chemo to start radiation.  I already had my consultation with the radiologist, and he wants me to come in for measuring (a 90 minute appointment) 1 week before my last chemo session, so we can start the radiation treatments the MONDAY after my last Taxol (the FRIDAY prior).  That means I'd only have 2 days inbetween!  I'll be asking again at my appointment on Friday and will post what my doctor says. I had some regrowth of hair in between a/c and taxol...well, maybe it was a fuzzy regrowth, ha ha...and that has all fallen out.  It was a little traumatic, because for the first time since losing everything, I was seeing the hairs on the pillow and inside my scarves again.  I really miss my hair.  I wonder how long it will take to fully "cover" my scalp once it does start growing back?  A month, maybe 2?  One of the cancer-support staff said you won't need a haircut until 6 months after treatment.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2009 06:30AM lcmag wrote: Hello Ladies! Had my 6th Taxol treatment on Friday, which means I'm halfway done with 6 more to go!!  I was so happy to have reached that milestone, when my doctor said "let me do a breast exam". He found a 'ridge' in the left breast (the one I call 'the OTHER one') that he wants me to have checked out with the breast surgeon.  Now, I've had a weird spot in that breast always - during my mammograms I have to have the left breast imaged 2 different ways.  I actually have to lean OVER the machine, and dangle my breast into the plates.  I'm pretty sure this is the same ridge the Onc felt on Friday - but I have been scared to death ever since. I know - all my pre-chemo scans came back clear, and the liklihood of a cancerous tumor creating itself and growing to the point where it can be felt in 3.5 months WHILE ON CHEMO is pretty damn slim.  But I still had to take 1mg of Lorazepam to sleep last night.  My appointment is at 3pm today. Other than that, the Taxol SEs are the same old, same old.  One toe on my right foot has gone numb, but it's not painfull or annoying, so I don't really care.  If that starts going on with my fingers I'll mention it to the doctor. Hair is definitely growing back.  It's darkening up, and really, really soft!  My eyebrows are back, eyelashes are coming in. Please pray for me today that the 'ridge' the oncologist felt is just my regular fibrous breast tissue, and not another form of cancer.  I just don't think I could take it if it's another cancer.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 08:51AM lcmag wrote: Polly - It's amazing how differently we all handle the treatments, isn't it?  My doctor said that the folks on 12 doses of Taxol generally have fewer side effects because the dose is smaller.  He also said that those of us on the 12 doses will feel worse as the treatments progress, but it's a gradual worsening (as if that makes it better). I hope that continues and that I won't start feeling truly horrible until I'm closer to the end.  This weeks' treatment marks my halfway point - 10 weeks are done and I have 10 more to go! Be well.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 07:19AM lcmag wrote: Pam - Yes, my doctor told me to take the B6 and the Zinc to prevent neuropathy.  GNC has 100mg B6 tablets and 30mg tablets of Zinc.  I bought a bottle of both.  I'm also taking a daily multivitamin (a gummy vitamin, it's like eating candy) which I haven't ever done before. I'm a little torn on the Avastin/SE issue - I understand that if they told patients about the worse side effects, fewer people (if any) would join, but as a patient suffering from unnecessarily harsh side effects, I would have liked to have known.  I lost 19 pounds and could only work every other week for 4 days at a time!!  If I could have spared myself even a fraction of that pain, it would have been worth it.  Oh well - as i said, water under the bridge at this point, right? I've been having some significant swelling under my arm on the side of my axillary disection - my right breast is swollen and barely fitting into my bra!  I'm seeing my surgeon today to see if this is normal, why did it start swelling after being fine for 2 months, can i take something/alter my diet to prevent swelling, etc. Be well today, ladies.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2009 08:55AM lcmag wrote: Hello All: I had my 8th of 12 Taxol treatments on Friday, things went fine.  I've been getting a bit more neuropathy tingles in my fingers, but nothing I can't deal with. My pinky toes, however, are a different story!  The nails are trying to come off and it is so painful that it is hard to walk normally.  I only have 4 more treatments left, and since my treatments are on Fridays, it's only 3 more weeks.  The hot flashes have calmed somewhat - i'm not certain if it is because I upped my vit E intake or because the chemo is finally killing off my ovaries - but whatever the reason, I'm glad to not be sweating through 3 sets of clothes a day. The weather in the Northeast the past few weekends has been awful, but it lends itself to lazing on the couch and watching movies all day.  I'm starting to really feel the fatigue EVERY day, not just on Sundays and Mondays. Even with radiation to follow, I feel like this is almost over.  I'm almost at the point where my life is going to start getting back to 'normal'. Hang in there ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 12:39PM lcmag wrote: Hello ladies! I just wanted to update folks on my radiation progress.  I have 12 more sessions left to go, and wow - is my skin NOT happy!  I have what looks like age spots all over my right breast, and the areola/nipple area is SO darkly 'tanned' that it looks dirty.  The radiation nurse said today that i was definitely getting "crispy" ha ha ha. I don't have any serious discomfort, but when I get home at night I do need to get out of my bra straight away and put on a bra-top tank top and rub a LOT of calendula gel on everything. I've been using Tom of Maine's deoderant and cornstarch for my armpit, but the nurse said to put the cornstarch on the breast as well, to help with any chaffing. My eyebrows decided to start growing back last week.  Right now it's more like a light grey stain where the brows used to be, but you can see the hairs poking through!  My eyelashes still aren't normal, but they can't be too far behind the eyebrows, right? At my last visit with my Oncologist, he wants me to do twice yearly infusions of Zofran, which is an osteoperosis medication shown to reduce the recurrance rates of breast cancer in post-menapausal women.  I'm going to go for it! I hope everyone is doing well and starting to put some of this behind you.  I want to forget that cancer ever happened to me, but if I do that I would also have to forget how strong I discovered I was, how resiliant.  I want to remember those things. Be well!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 06:18AM lcmag wrote: Hello Ladies! I had my 4th Taxol treatment on Friday, and really, everything has proceeded exactly as the last 3!  I feel fine Friday afternoon and evenings, fine Saturday during the day, but a little tired at night.  Sunday morning is good, but by Sunday afternoon it's time to find the couch and some good tv! Monday I work a half day, come home and sleep for the rest of the afternoon.  I feel mostly back to normal today, but that fatigue seems to seep around the edges, if you know what i mean. I had one fingernail starting to fall off, now I have 4.  Both thumbs along with the index and middle finger of the right hand.  The nails are detaching from the top down and are about halfway off.  I think I'm just going to put one of those teeny tiny bandaids over the top, so no gunk or dirt can get under the nail.  It doesn't hurt, but it sure looks peculiar - i'm sure it will look worse when/if they actually fall out. My eyebrows are like rats on a sinking ship - but oddly enough, 3 days after they fall out, they start growing back again, only really fine and thin.  The eyelashes just fall out!  I have not noticed any hair regrowth so far, and I'm starting to wonder if hair regrowth on Taxol is just a myth. The hot flashes are still there, still waking me up 4-5 times a night.  My doctor reccommended Vit. E, so I've been taking that daily since Saturday.  I can't say that I've noticed any difference.  He offered to give me a mild anti-depressant to help me sleep, but I'm at a point where I really don't want to put anything in my body that isn't ABSOLUTELY necessary.  I actually had to go out and buy one of those daily pill organizers to keep all the medicines straight, and to make sure I'm taking the proper meds on the correct days! Have any of you heard about doing chemo and rads at the same time?  I'm scheduled to have my final Taxol treatment on 11/13, and I would like to overlap the radiation treatments (24) for the last 2 weeks of chemo, so that I'm done the week prior to Christmas.  I have heard of a couple of people at the cancer center doing both, but I haven't heard of any breast cancer patients doing them at the same time.  A question about working was asked last week - my treatments are on Friday, so I take the morning off and work from home in the afternoons.  On Mondays I work half of the day at the office and the other half at home.  Tuesday - Thursday I work full time at the office.  My employer has been phenominal to me during my diagnosis, surgery and treatment.  There has never been a discussion about short or long term disability, I can go home when I feel tired, come in early or late if I need to, etc.  I can't imagine how I would have gotten through as much as I have without their complete and unwavering support.  I know it has made a huge difference on my stress levels and my feeling like a productive member of the community, which is important to me.  I'm not a work-a-holic by any means, but I enjoy my job, I enjoy being here and maintaining my routine.  They have supported me in that this whole time, and I am truly blessed to be a part of this organization. Be well today ladies!  The road we travel is harder than most, but it is because we link hands and travel it together, that we make it to the end.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 11:19AM lcmag wrote: Polly - I am going to Puerto Rico 2 months after finishing up chemo & radiation, so I understand how you feel about having at least an inch or so of hair growth.  Not only do I want to relax and sit in the sun (with sunscreen on, of course!) while I'm away, I don't want to have to worry about my head getting sunburned! I have had 4 Taxol treatments so far, this week is my 5th, and I agree with you about the S/Es, so far so good!  I'm tired Sunday and Monday, my fingernails are falling off, my eyelashes are gone most of my eyebrows too.  But i'm not throwing up for 5 days straight like I was on a/c. I think the 100mg of B6 and 60mgs of Zinc have kept the neuralgia away, and with no Neulasta or Neupagin shots, I'm not dealing with any significant bone pain. Here's hoping that continues! Be well today, ladies!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 01:04PM lcmag wrote: oksheri - Your surgeon removed your port in his office?  What was that like?  I have #11 of 12 Taxol tomorrow, and was thinking that I'd like to get the port out before I start radiation.  If the surgeon can do it in their office, I may actually be able to do that! You must be so releived to be DONE! lcmag
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 12:55PM lcmag wrote: Diane / DiDi 95% of my hair fell out while on a/c.  I had a three week break between a/c and taxol, and during that time the 95% started growing back very slowly.  3 (weekly) Taxol treatments later, the 5% hair that remained during a/c all fell out!!! I have ONE more taxol treatment left and my hair is REALLY growing back but that 5% still hasn't come back, so I have bald spots and thin patches that prevent me from taking the scarves off.  I expect that 5% to come back once the Taxol is out of my system. My ankles are swelling in very odd and uncomfortable ways and I try to stay off them as much as possible.  Everyone at work seems to be getting sick and I feel like I should wear a surgical mask the next two days so I don't come down with anything that would push back my final chemo treatment. I meet with the radiologist for my measuring appointment tomorrow!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2009 07:46AM lcmag wrote: Hey Junies! Had my 4th Taxol on Friday and everything has been exactly the same as the 3 previous.  I feel great on Friday and Saturday, okay Sunday morning, tired Sunday afternoon and exhausted Sunday night. I find the hot flashes and night sweats to be the absolute WORST on Sunday nights, and I can't sleep for more than 40 minutes without having to either rip OFF the covers or pull them back on.  The doctor prescribed me a very low dose of Zoloft, but I have some fears about taking it. I've never been a person who struggles with depression - anxiety and worry are more my forte - and when I was first diagnosed and undergoing all those surgeries, I started having panic attacks.  I was able to practice some breathing excercises that got me through them, but until I started on a/c, I was having them often.  I am fearfull that the Zoloft will either bring back the panic attacks or make me unable to stop them on my own. When I was on a/c they gave me a perscription for Ativan, and that helped me with nausea but made me extremely tired.  I think I will try the Ativan that I have left over on Sunday nights and see if that will at least allow me to sleep.  If so, I'd rather refill that perscription that start the zoloft.  Also, it takes about 2 weeks for the Zoloft to take effect and by that time, I'll only have 3 more weeks left on taxol..........is it worth introducing another chemical into my body?  I'm just not sure. My eyebrows are growing back after literally JUST falling out!  My eyelashes, too.  It's amazing, really.  My fuzzies all fell out and REAL HAIR started growing back!  My fiancee said to me last weekend that my head was finally soft again, and not pricking him.  I noticed just this morning that it's taking on a darker color, too.  I think this might actually be my real hair.  Real hair is growing back in OTHER places too - places that haven't seen hair since I last shaved on the freaking Fourth of July.  It's all very fine, light hair.  My fingernails are a mess, tho.  I have 6 that are splitting at the nail bed and my pinky toe nails will probably be gone by the end of the week, if they last that long.  While it looks gross, as long as I am not in any pain or feeling any discomfort, I can deal with it. I think I may be getting some finger-tip numbing, but it's so hard to tell, because I've cut my fingernails back very short, and with all the anti-bacterial hand gel I've been using, the skin is so dry and cracked. All in all, I have been feeling very positive lately.  I feel like I can see the end and getting there might not be as hard as getting to THIS point.  Be well today, ladies!  Take a moment and do something for yourself, even if it's 5 minutes of peace while looking at the start of the fall folliage.  You deserve it!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 06:56AM lcmag wrote: ALL CLEAR! Thank you everyone for the thoughts and prayers - I met with my breast surgeon on Monday afternoon and she did a very thorough exam of both breasts.  The "ridge" that the oncologist felt was just the transition from breast tissue to chest muscle.  She even had me feel where the same ridge occurs on the right breast, but because of the surgeries on that breast and the residual swelling, you really have to kind of dig in to feel it. I could not beleive the releif that swept over me.  I had been pre-occupied with this 'ridge' all damn weekend - terrified that something else was growing inside me.  I appreciate that my oncologist is so thorough and cautious, but I really didn't need the stress!  Now that I feel like I can breathe again, I got another recommendation for something to assist with the neuropathy: glutamine powder.  You take 2 tablespoons a day.  I have developed some numbness in one toe and 2 fingers, so we will see if this reverses it or just prevents it from getting worse. I took 2 Ativan on Sunday night and slept like a baby!  I think I'll have the doctor refill this perscription instead of starting on the Zoloft.  I only have 6 treatments left (I get them on Fridays), and I'd rather just take the Ativan on the days I know I can't sleep (Friday & Sunday) than take something every day. BIG HUGE CONGRATS to everyone who has finished chemo so far - I can't wait to join the ranks.  After this week, I can count down my treatments on one hand or one foot!  it seems like a silly milestone, but one that I can't wait to reach. Hang in there, ladies!  Huge thanks and hugs to you all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 07:05AM lcmag wrote: Polly - CONGRATS on finishing up rads!  I had my last rads on Tuesday.  The fatigue dropped on me like a bomshell 3 days after starting the boosts, and I'm still pretty tired. I had my first HAIRCUT on Friday of last week - it was so nice to go to the salon and get pampered like I used to.  They did the cut for free, and that was a nice surprise.  My eyebrows are almost back, tho a little thin and my eyelashes are still taking their time coming back. I was AMAZED at how dark/red my skin got during radiation and I'm wondering how long it will take this "tan" to fade and the skin to get back to its normal color. I had/have a lot of aches and pains as well - mainly my hips, lower back and shoulders.  I can't tell if it's fading because it's only been 2 days, but I hope that leaves sooner rather than later. I have follow up appointments in 2 weeks with my radiologist and oncologist and I see the surgeon next week to talk about removing the port-a-cath.  Once that thing is out I think I'll really start feeling normal again. It's so strange to not have a daily appointment, or a standing weekly appointment. It's not that i will MISS it, it just seems odd to not have to plan around it or think about it. Be well!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 10:51AM lcmag wrote: Hello Tom(n Di)! I am done with chemo and halfway through radiation.  My hair is growing back like ganbusters, but the eyebrows and eyelashes are still MIA. In regard to the racing thoughts/anxiety it sounds like a bit of post-traumatic stress, but remember that we've had something MAJOR to think about in our heads over the last year.  Something that is always there, nagging at you, creeping into your other thoughts.  It's hard to "turn off" your brain when it's been working overtime for so long. Now that Di doesn't have the cancer to think about 24/7, her mind is trying to find other things to obsess about.  Di would do well to talk to her primary care physician about anti-anxiety medications coupled with counseling.  She just needs to teach her brain that it's okay to be at rest.  I've been taking lorazepam (.50mg)when my anxiety gets too much and I can't turn my head off, but I have been relying on it less and less as each week passes. Happy Holidays to everyone and a blessed, cancer-free New Year!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2010 10:56AM lcmag wrote: On Friday the 26th, it was 1 year since the start of my chemotherapy.  I can't beleive it's been 1 year already!  I have just started making the rounds of doctors for my 6 month check-ups (Gyno, Breast Surgeon, MRI and finally the Oncologist), and it's a little scary - but I know that my body was cancer free prior to beginning chemo, so I'm pretending this is my 1 year check up! Congrats to all of us - it sort of makes me happy that this thread isn't seeing much activity and I hope it's because we're all getting back to LIFE!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee
